reporting-org.narrative: International Union for Conservation of Nature

title.narrative: SUSTAIN - Africa

description.narrative: SUSTAIN-Africa is an initiative to implement Sustainable Development Goals in African growth corridors. The aim is to facilitate greening of growth that is inclusive and climate-resilient. The initiative is implemented at the local, national and continental levels, linking practice on the ground to policy change at corridor and Africa-wide levels. It integrates water, land and ecosystem management with sustainable business to demonstrate inclusive green growth using the landscapes approach.
Sustainability and Inclusion Strategy for Growth Corridors in Africa

Water security - solutions for climate-resilient, sustainable water management for livelihoods, production and ecosystems, reducing water related risks for communities and business. Climate change resilience – working with farmers, communities and business on the management and restoration of landscapes to lower risks to food security, adapt to climate change, and support inclusive new value chains with low-carbon impact. Green business innovation – collaboration with small and large business on the essential contribution of ecosystem services to development and economic growth Inclusion - strengthening the rights-based approach and empowering local communities to participate, influence and benefit from corridor development. Partnerships – building synergies among communities, business, civil society and government for long-term results on the ground and for better policies and business strategies.

title.narrative: SUSTAIN-Africa Borchure
Project photo
Sustain initiative

SO1 - SR 1.1. Institutions working at local to transboundary levels are integrating water, land and ecosystem management and enabling participation, joint action and cooperation needed to strengthen rights, resilience and investment
28.% of women in decision-making structures of water resources user groups

comment.narrative: 20% in Cahora Bassa Landscape 30% in Kilombero Cluster 27.5% in Sumbawanga cluster (27 out of 63 village water committee members and 75 out of 217 WUA members) In Sumbawanga cluster, out of the 5 villages that reported WUAs, only 1 woman had leadership position as a Chairperson in Mtowisa

title.narrative: 4. Enhanced rural livelihoods through improved water and food security, and climate resilience (Scope = villages & communites of demonstration landscapes )
14. Annual HH income and % increase generated through environmental goods & services (EGS[1])

comment.narrative: 6% of total HH income generated through EGS 850'00TSH and 9,8% of income (92500TSH) generated through EGS for KilomberoCluster 3'020'000 TSH and 7.9% of income generated through EGS for Sumbawanga cluster 20'809MzM and 0.3% of income generated through EGS for Cahora Bassa Landscape

title.narrative: SO2 -SR2.2. Ecosystem management is improved to include measures specifically targeted at strengthening food security
52.% of farmers/communities practicing sustainable land and forest management practices at cluster level.

comment.narrative: In Kilombero cluster 36% of the farmers practice sustainable land and forest management. They are doing contour farming, hedge rows,terraces, crop rotations, and tree planting. In Sumbawanga no communities had the forest management plan, and village land use plan. In Cahora Bassa Landscape 6.4% of household engage in conservation agriculture, 14.4% in planting vetivar and 24.3% have dug contour ridges so in total 45.1 of the household are engaged in sustainable management practices

title.narrative: SO1 -SR1.3. Wastewater management is reducing the ecosystem, health and economic costs of water pollution
44.% of Water User Associations accessing water quality data

comment.narrative: In Kilombero cluster, 1 Water user association (JUWAIMIU) accessing water quality of 3 associations found within the surveyed area. WUAs and COWSOs had no access to water quality data. Putting it differently, there were 0% of 6 Water Users associations accessing water quality data in Sumbawanga Cluster. 0% Cahora Bassa Landscape, number of WUA not clearly established and thus not integrated in the average % calculation of the baseline value

title.narrative: SO2 -SR2.1. Landscape-level management and restoration of ecosystems is diversifying and improving the sustainability of farm, forest and wetland production systems.
47.Number and type of new or improved type of landscape and restoration plans
48.Number and type of new multistakeholder landscape management agreements to diversify and improve the sustainabilityof farm, forest and wetland production systems
50.Number & type of new supportive by-laws (supporting the effective implementation of landscape management and restoration plans) formulated and endorsed within the targeted cluster
SO2 -SR2.3. New or existing value chains are linking investments in ecosystems and natural resources and diversified primary production with economic development strategies
57. % of target smallholder farmers at cluster level that engages in diversified nature based income generation opportunities

comment.narrative:
In Kilombero cluster, 11% (45 out of 403) of targeted smallholder farmers at cluster level are engaging in diversified nature based income generation opportunities. The nature based activities include: charcoal making, bee keeping, fishing farming, tourists and Mushrooms
81.1% (197 out of 243 HH) of smallholder farmers in Sumawanga Cluster were engaged in diversified nature based income generation activities.
3.4% (18 out of 529) of household are engaged in diversified nature based income generation activities in Cahora Bassa Landscape

title.narrative: 56.Type of new investments in climate smart and sustainable nature based value chains by the public and private sector at cluster level

SO3 -SR3.3. Business development partnerships are supporting expanded participation of small-scale producers and processors in small enterprise opportunities created through diversification of landscapes
75.Number and type of new business development /innovation initiatives for diversified and nature-based income generating activities at cluster level
SO4 -SR4.2. National and Corridor-level policies and strategies influenced and supported by enhanced skills, technical know-how and awareness across stakeholders at multiple levels
86. Examples of (emerging) cases/situations where policy makers and/or business leaders show increased leadership for inclusive green growth strategies at national and corridor levels
85.Number and type of national and corridor -level policy and/or business leaders that are informed, sensitised & trained on inclusive green growth strategies through SUSTAIN
87. Total number of people informed, sensitised or trained on inclusive green growth strategies through SUSTAIN dis-aggregated by a) community and professionals and b) policy/business leaders
89.Number and type of new standardized methodologies and tools for IGG practice adopted at corridor level
94. Number and type of new dialogue events conducted at cluster level involving community and professional organisations
SO4 -SR4.3. Project Management is enabling implementation with IUCN members, business, knowledge institutes and civil society partners and stakeholders at all levels
95.Monthly PMG meetings are taking place
100.Amount of co-funding raised

SO1 -SR1.2. Implementation of integrated water resources management and application of ecosystem services as natural infrastructure is making water infrastructure more sustainable, improving cost and water-use efficiency and strengthening climate and disaster resilience
36.Number and type of investment plans that includes water-related risk assessments and risk-reducing solutions at national/corridor level
3. Institutional and behavioral change of the public and private sector supporting inclusive green growth( Cluster level)
11.Number of new partnerships formed with private sector entities fostering inclusive green growth at cluster level
2. Institutional and behavioral change of the public and private sector supporting inclusive green growth.(National/Corridor level)
5. Number and type of relevant policy, resolutions, decrees, legislative proposals, investment plans,…improved or created at corridor/national level to promote inclusive green growth
SO3 -SR3.1.New partnerships (*) match business and social investors with communities or land and water institutions to build long-term synergies between development and conservation
67. Number (%) of targeted smallholders accessing loans from financial institutions, incl. the Green Guarantee Facility or other microcredit facility funds

comment.narrative:
7% (17 out of 243) of smallholder farmers accessed loans for different purposes from different sources in sumbawanga cluster
0.8% of household (4 out of 529) accessed loans from GGF and 1.5% (8 out of 529) from other institution in Cahora Bassa Landscape

title.narrative: 65.Number & type of new partnerships at cluster level that induce bussines enterprises to operate sustainably and inclusively .
5.Restored and productive landscapes that demonstrate improved protection and conservation of ecosystems and biodiversity
19.% of wetlands that are managed more effectively

comment.narrative: 0 out of 8 wetlands in Kilolo and Ifakara (0%) 0 out of 15 wetlands in Sumbawanga (0%) There is not wetland in Cahora Bassa Landscape

title.narrative: 18.Number of hectares of forest reserve where deforestation, degradation and illegal logging have been avoided
17.Quantity (ton) of carbon dioxide captured by Forest put under sustainable management during the lifespan of SUSTAIN intervention
16.Number of hectares of land and forests put under sustainable management
